Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Lagrangian Sensing in Large Scale Cyber-Physical Infrastructure Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project includes the development of theory and algorithms, the design of a system architecture, and the prototyping, testing and large-scale deployment of two mobile sensing platforms. The two applications are highway traffic estimation and river flow estimation using GPS-equipped smartphones. The algorithms run online, gather mobile data and send it to a server, which uses inverse modeling to estimate the state of the system. It broadcasts information back to the smartphones and to the internet. A field operational test, called Mobile Millennium is aimed at reaching thousands of users in California. The river flow monitoring project is aimed at deploying a hundred drifters in the Sacramento Delta.

The contributions are in the field of Lagrangian sensing in large-scale cyber-physical infrastructure systems. "Lagrangian" refers to a form of sensing in which sensors measure quantities along their trajectories; "cyber-physical" refers to the flow of information and computing in a system governed by physical phenomena. The project investigates the following question: how to reconstruct the state of a distributed system from mobile sensors which cannot control their motion? The mathematical techniques used include inverse modeling, applied to partial differential equations.

This project addresses some important issues related to transportation and clean water. With the free downloadable smartphone software, commuters have real-time traffic information to increase their travel efficiency. By involving students from underrepresented minorities, the UC Berkeley Disabled Student Program, and the Berkeley High School, this research provides a valuable opportunity for students to develop their interest in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award started in 2008, a time when the smartphone era was just at its infancy: the iPhone 1 did not have a GPS, and the Android did not even exist at the time. When the proposal was written, the goal of the project was to create a framework for integration of mobile data (such as GPS data collected from smartphones) into distributed parameter models of physical phenomena (such as road traffic, hydrodynamics). The grant proposed to developed the proper mathematical tools to perform data assimilation at large scale on partial differential equation models of these cyber physical systems. It also proposed to demonstrate these techniques on at least two benchmark applications: highway traffic and hydrodynamics of tidally foced waterways. 

The project was a success beyond all expectations. Out of the project came many articles on the mathematical foundations of viability theory (used in Lagrangian data assimilation), numerous journal artlcles, numerous awards (including the Ruberti Prize from the IEEE, and the Huber Prize from the ASCE). The Mobile Millennium project also became the flagship university collaboration of Nokia, it became one of the launch projects of the CITRIS instititute. Numerous of the students who were part of this project and funded by the CAREER or associated with the CAREER project became professors at lead institutions in the US (MIT, UIUC, UT Austin, Purdue), the other students joined leading companies in the field and are now in leadership positions at Google, Facebook, Microsoft in the mobility / traffic / maps divisions of these companies. The primary investigator built a multimillion dollar project (over $20M today) on traffic management based on the initial CAREER step, and has now become the Director of the Institute of Transportation Studies (ITS) at UC Berkeley, the flagship academic research institute in the US on transportation. 

The award advanced science, engineering and technology. A new mathematical framework was developed throughout the award, and the PI is now preparing a second book on this topic, in addition to the numerous articles published on the topic. The seminal article on the Mobile Century experiment, written as part of the CAREER award, is the most cited article in the history of the journal Transportation Research -- Part C. The pilot project Mobile Millennium created the seed of a software system which numerous of the students have now ported to the private sector, as part of their jobs. The work led to the first procurement of GPS data by the State of California, which was administered and organized by the Mobile Millennium team. The project was also the seed for the Floating Sensor Network system, the first fleet of 100 motorized mobile water sensors capable of transmitting water quality measurements and information about water currents in real time to a backend system, while the backend system was integrating the Lagrangian data in real-time into hydrodynamics models. The Floating Sensor Network was deployed in numerous field operational tests to showcase its capabilities. It routinely was launched in the Sacramento Delta (Sacramento river in particular and Georgianna Slough), in the San Francisco Bay, and in Stillwater Oklahoma, where it was used by the Department of Homeland Security and the US Army Corps of Engineers to test floods with levee breaches. Finally, the CAREER award opened the door for new research avenues. Today, with the explosion of mobile technology, distributed control of traffic has become a reality, and the group which originiated from the CAREER grant is the leading group in the US in the field of integrated corridor management, with pioneering work done in Southern California. 

In conclusion this CAREER grant has enabled a junior faculty to seed his research, and to bring incredible visibility to it, way beyond expectations: leverage from $400K to $20...
